Description: Body sherd of Chian Wild Goat Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior glazed streaky black; part of lotus bud in added white outline with added red centres; below, two white lines; exterior: painted decoration of frieze of geese to left (on left, part of wing and tail feathers of one goose; on right, beak, part of head, neck, body and part of wing of second); pendant roundels, hooked swastika and dot rosettes as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Lemos describes the sherd as being in the style of the Würzburg chalices, but dated later than those chalices because she considers the style of the drawing to be debased and because of the elementary and isolated interior decoration (Lemos 1991, 72-3). Unlike most other sherds in this category, however, the interior decoration is not quite so isolated. The sherd ought to belong to the later period of the Wild Goat Style since, although the metope pattern decoration on the exterior surface is typical of the Wild Goat Style, the lotus decoration on the interior, which is absent during this period, is typical in the later reserved Animal Chalice, Grand and Chalice styles. Furthermore, geese are extremely rarely portrayed in the Mature Animal Style.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 38; p. 73; p. 237, no. 173)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0402) (phase 2)
